summary: J. C. King was the Chief of the Western Hemisphere (WH) Division within the CIA. A memorandum from J.C. King to the Deputy Director (Plans) requests approval for the revised Related Mission Directive for Mexico, which outlines objectives related to countering communism and maintaining friendly relations with the Mexican government. The documents also mention CIA activities related to assassination plots against Fidel Castro and Patrice Lumumba, as well as discussions about 'Executive Action'. King's role appears to be primarily administrative and supervisory, involved in the approval and oversight of CIA operations and directives within the Western Hemisphere, particularly in Mexico and Cuba. The documents span from 1952 to 1976, indicating a long period of involvement in CIA activities.
significance: While J. C. King is mentioned in documents related to sensitive CIA operations, including potential assassination plots against foreign leaders, the documents do not directly link J. C. King to the JFK assassination. His significance lies in his role as a high-ranking CIA official overseeing operations in the Western Hemisphere during a period of intense Cold War activity.
